intro: Monochoria vaginalis var. plantaginea, commonly known as the broadleaf water hyacinth, is a floating aquatic plant native to Southeast Asia. It has broad, heart-shaped leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length and can float on the surface of water bodies. The plant produces small, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in clusters, often with three to five petals. It thrives in still or slow-moving freshwater environments and is often found in ponds, lakes, and wetlands. Due to its rapid growth and invasive nature, it can outcompete native species and disrupt aquatic ecosystems.
